awd_titl_txt: Investigating the Relationship Between the Structure and Mechanical Behavior of the Lamina Cribrosa
awd_abstract_narration:
Glaucoma is a blinding disease caused by the progressive death of retinal ganglion cells and their axons in the lamina cribrosa.  The lamina cribrosa is a fenestrated connective tissue structure in the optic nerve head that mechanically supports axons as they exit the eye.  Glaucoma is the leading cause of blindness in the US, affecting an estimated 3 million Americans. The incidence and severity of the disease strongly correlate with the intraocular pressure, though the level of the intraocular pressure at which glaucoma damage is detected varies widely.    Lowering the intraocular pressure can slow axon loss. The effectiveness of the treatment varies among patients and 10% of patients diagnosed with glaucoma eventually go blind.   The PIs hypothesize that deformation caused by the intraocular pressure in the optic nerve head causes axonal damage. Moreover regional variations in the microstructure of the lamina cribrosa lead to regions of greater damage. In this project, the PIs will measure the pressure-induced strains and the structure of the lamina cribrosa.  These will be used to create models of the lamina cribrosa to determine why certain regions exhibit more deformation and higher stress levels. Understanding the relationship between the optic nerve head structure and deformation may lead to the identification of new structural biomarkers for the early detection of glaucoma using non-invasive imaging and to the development of more effective patient-specific treatment strategies. Axon damage produces permanent vision loss in adult glaucoma and early detection is key to preserving vision.  The project will also benefit engineering education by providing research opportunities to graduate, undergraduate and high school students that involves state of the art experimental and modeling methods. 

The objective of the research is to investigate the extent that anatomical structure and microstructural features lead to regional variations in the strain and stress levels. We will apply a recently developed inflation test, which uses multiphoton imaging and digital volume correlation, to measure the three-dimensional deformation field in the lamina cribrosa and surrounding peripapillary sclera. The inflation test method also yields measurements of the anatomical structure of the optic nerve head tissues. We will analyze these for regional differences and for eye-specific correlations between the structural and strain measurements. The data will be used to develop specimen-specific micromechanical models to study the deformation kinematics of the fibrous network microstructure of the lamina cribrosa and the structure-properties relationship of the optic nerve head tissue. Finally, the outcomes of the experiments and lower scale micromechanical models will be used to develop specimen- specific finite element models of the optic nerve head and sclera to systematically evaluate the contributions of microstructural and anatomic features to the spatial variations in the strain and stress state.  The work will advance fundamental understanding of the biomechanics of the optic nerve head and elucidate the relationship between the structure and material behavior through computational modeling and statistical analysis of the eye-specific LC anatomical structure, microstructure, deformation.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project was to study the structure and mechanical behavior of the lamina cribrosa in the optic nerve head.  The lamina cribrosa is a tissue that is a part of the eye wall. The tissue is made up of a stack of plates with holes that line up to form channels for the axonal fibers of the optic nerves to exit the eye to form the optic nerve cable. This optic nerve cable delivers the visual signals from the retina to the visual cortex of the brain.  The nerve fibers become damaged in the lamina cribrosa in glaucoma. Overtime, this leads to the death of the entire neuron. This process of neural degeneration eventually causes complete vision loss in glaucoma.  We know from previous studies that the axons becomes damaged in the lamina cribrosa if the eye pressure is increased and stays elevated for a long time. The eye pressure is checked yearly during annual checkups to screen for glaucoma.  However, not everyone starts to develop glaucoma at the eye pressure and the differences may be caused by differences in the structure and mechanical properties of the lamina cribrosa.

 The goal of this project was to understand the microstructure of the lamina cribrosa and how they influence the strain response in normal and glaucoma eyes.  To did this, we developed methods to characterize how the lamina cribrosa deforms under an applied pressure. We also analyzed the microstructure of the lamina for human eyes and mouse eyes.  We then developed specimen-specific models of the structure of the lamina and used computational models to investigate how the different features of the tissues of the eye affected the strain response.  

The main results of the studies are: 1) the lamina cribrosa of eyes diagnosed with glaucoma are stiffer than those from normal eyes.  2) The strain response to pressure of the lamina cribrosa becomes stiffer with age.  3) The strain response is more compliant in those lamina cribrosa with lower connective tissue volume, more curved beams, and longer beams, and higher beam connectivity.  The lamina cribrosa of glaucoma eyes had smaller pores than normal eyes, but no other microstructural features were significantly different with glaucoma.  The curvature of the lamina cribrosa of glaucoma eyes had a significantly higher curvature.  The modeling study for the mouse lamina showed that the strains of the axonal tissues also depend on the size, shape, and reside are larger for larger pore area and more elongated pores. 

These results reveals how the different microstructural features of the lamina affects the strain response. They also suggest that the mechanical properties of the lamina cribrosa becomes stiffer in glaucoma eyes.  The methods and findings developed in this project has enabled us to develop a new experimental method to measure the strains in the patients during routine ophthalmologist visits and new modeling methods to create eye-specific models of the optic nerve head.  This is the first step for developing a method to screen for biomechanical factors for glaucoma and for evaluating the effectiveness of pressure-lowering treatments for glaucoma.  

This project has provided funding and other support for 3 PhD students (2 men, 1 woman), 3 undergraduate researchers, and 1 high school student from the women in science and engineering program.  Two of the PhD students have graduated and are now postdoctoral fellows in the BME departments at Yale University and Columbia University.  

 

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Thao (Vicky) D Nguyen
